title: A new solution to the collective action problem: the paradox of voter turnout
abstract:
Macy's work offers a potential solution to the paradox of voter turnout. The stochastic\ud
learning theory of voter turnout (Kanazawa 1998) posits that citizens perceive a\ud
correlation between their behavior (voting versus abstention) and the outcome of\ud
collective action (win versus loss for their candidate), and that they interpret the\ud
outcome as a reinforcer or a punisher. The theory can solve the paradox of voter\ud
turnout because now p, the probability that one's vote is or appears decisive, equals\ud
approximately .500 in the calculus-of-voting model (instead of p 0). I use General\ud
Social Survey data to test the theory. The empirical results indicate that citizens\ud
make their turnout decisions according to the "Win-Stay, Lose-Shift" pattern predicted\ud
by the stochastic learning theory, especially if there are no strong third-party\ud
candidates
